Joaquín Martínez-Minaya
  • Research
  • Teaching
  • Supplementary material

During my 9 years of experience as a researcher, I have collaborated with diverse research groups on projects spanning regional, national, and international scopes. My dedication has remained steadfastly centered on the realms of Statistics and Data Science, with substantial contributions made in three distinct research lines:

L1. Spatio-Temporal Statistics in Species Distribution Modeling My doctoral thesis centered on this first research line, emphasizing the application of spatio-temporal modeling to plant and marine species. This work laid the foundation for my expertise in understanding and analyzing species distribution.

L2. Bayesian Computational Methods Originating in the latter stages of my doctoral research, I ventured into developing an R package for implementing models in the context of compositional data. To date, Bayesian computational methods, particularly employing techniques such as the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo Methods (MCMC), remain a cornerstone of my ongoing research endeavors.

L3. Bayesian Statistical Learning in Health and Environment This is the most recent addition to my research portfolio, this line emerged during my postdoctoral tenure. The application of Bayesian learning principles in health and environmental contexts has become a substantial part of my current projects, with a particular emphasis on health applications.
